proof:
For each set $P \in \mathcal{P}$, we apply Lemma 3.1 to the induced subgraph $H[P]$ with the parameter $d_{\text{remove}}$. This provides a graph $R_P$ with a degree of at most $d_{\text{remove}}$, such that the maximum clique in the graph $H[P] - R_P$ has a size no larger than $16 \ln(n) \frac{d_{\text{filter}}}{d_{\text{remove}}} + 10$.
We define the graph $R$ to be the union of all these individual $R_P$ graphs: $R := \cup_{P \in \mathcal{P}} R_P$. Because the vertex set $Q$ is disjoint from all sets in the collection $\mathcal{P}$, it follows that no edge in $R$ is incident to any vertex in $Q$. Additionally, for any given $P \in \mathcal{P}$, since $R_P$ is a subgraph of $R$ and the vertex sets in $\mathcal{P}$ are mutually disjoint, the subgraph of $R$ induced by the vertices of $P$ is exactly $R_P$. Consequently, the largest clique in the graph $(H - R)[P]$, which is identical to $H[P] - R_P$, has a size that does not exceed $16 \ln(n) \frac{d_{\text{filter}}}{d_{\text{remove}}} + 10$.
